quiz.title: Object-Relational Mapping Quiz
quiz.description:
It's time to check your knowledge! Use this quiz to create a custom study guide. Note any answers that were marked incorrect, so you can study the relevant material and try this quiz again.

If you don't know the answer to a question, please do not guess. Instead, select "I don't know". It's OK not to know everything and to admit when we're unsure.

questions.question_text: Object Relational Mapping (ORM) is the technique of accessing a relational database using what type of programming language? Choose the best answer.

answers.comments: Whoooo!! Object Relational Mapping is a way for our programs to manage database data by "mapping" database tables to classes and instances of classes to rows in those tables.
answers.comments_html:
Whoooo!! Object Relational Mapping is a way for our programs to manage database
data by "mapping" database tables to classes and instances of classes to rows in
those tables.

answers.comments: Sort of. We can use Python, but we can also use other languages.
Not quite. There's SQL under-the-hood, but it's not the star of the show.
Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: To follow a pattern of logical design, if we have a Car Python class, what should the corresponding SQL table be named?

answers.comments: Perfect! The table holds many cars, so it makes sense to call it cars.
Not quite. Does the table hold one car or many?
Not quite. Conventionally, our table names and class names use matching terminology, except one is singular and the other is plural.
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. Conventionally, our table names and class names use matching
terminology, except one is singular and the other is plural.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following code:

class Car:
  def __init__(self, make, model):
    self.make = make
    self.model = model

In order to "map" this Car class to a cars database table, what needs to be done first?
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Mapping Database Records to Python Objects

answers.comments: Yes! We can't map the class to anything if there's no database.
We actually need something else first. What stores tables?
Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: What are the steps needed to write a class that is mapped to a database table? Select all that apply.
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Mapping Database Records to Python Objects

answers.text: Create a table with the same name as the class, but pluralized
answers.comments: Exactly! If the class is called Cat, the table should be called cats.

answers.text: Match the names of the table's columns to the attributesof the class
answers.html: Match the names of the table's columns to the attributes of the class
answers.comments: So true! We need the columns and attributes to match, so that we know which data we're manipulating.
answers.comments_html:
So true! We need the columns and attributes to match, so that we know which
data we're manipulating.

answers.text: Match the names of the table's columns to class variables
answers.html: Match the names of the table's columns to class variables
answers.comments: Not quite. Remember that each row in the table is represented by an object, or an instance of a class. What might that mean?
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. Remember that each row in the table is represented by an object, or
an instance of a class. What might that mean?

answers.text: Create a table with the exact same name as the class
answers.comments: Not quite. The table name and class name should be similar, but not exactly the same.
answers.comments_html:
Not quite. The table name and class name should be similar, but not exactly the
same.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text:
Consider a table with the following columns:

| id | make | model |

Which code snippet creates a class with instance methods mapped to these table columns, following ORM conventions?
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Mapping Python Classes to a Database

answers.text: class Car: def __init__(self, make, model): self.id = None self.make = make self.model = model
answers.html:
class Car:

  def __init__(self, make, model):
    self.id = None
    self.make = make
    self.model = model
answers.comments: Correct! The id is set to None because it should only be set after the record is saved to the database.
answers.comments_html: Correct! The id is set to None because it should only be set after the record is saved to the database.

answers.text: class Car: def __init__(self, make, model, id): self.id = id self.make = make self.model = model
answers.html:
class Car:
  def __init__(self, make, model, id):
    self.id = id
    self.make = make
    self.model = model
answers.comments: Hmm, something is missing. Take a look at the id. The id shouldn't be saved until after the record has been saved to the database.
answers.comments_html:
Hmm, something is missing. Take a look at the id. The id shouldn't be saved
until after the record has been saved to the database.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: Why do we use a dedicated method save() to insert a row into a table instead of saving the record in __init__?
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Mapping Python Classes to a Database

answers.text: We don't want to couple the creation of objects with saving records to a database
answers.html:
We don't want to couple the creation of objects with saving records to a
database
answers.comments: Yes! This makes our code more modular, so we can choose to create objects or save to the database. This is much more flexible than coupling both functions in the same method.
answers.comments_html:
Yes! This makes our code more modular, so we can choose to create objects or
save to the database. This is much more flexible than coupling both functions in
the same method.

answers.text: We might need to create objects without saving them to the database
answers.comments: Exactly! We may need to manipulate those objects after certain tasks have run, and then save them.
answers.comments_html:
Exactly! We may need to manipulate those objects after certain tasks have run,
and then save them.

answers.text: We can't set the attributes and save the record in the same method
answers.html: We can't set the attributes and save the record in the same method
answers.comments: Not quite. We can do both of these things in a method if we want.

answers.text: There's no real reason. It's just a convention
answers.html: There's no real reason. It's just a convention
answers.comments: We do have reasons, though this is a convention.
Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: How does an ORM (Object-Relational Map) map between our object-oriented code and a database table? Match each OO concept to the corresponding database structure:
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

answers.text: Value of an attribute for an instance of a class
answers.left: Value of an attribute for an instance of a class

questions.question_text: Using an ORM enables us to save entire Python objects in our database.
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Mapping Python Classes to a Database

answers.comments: This one is a bit tricky! We are not able to save the object itself into our database; instead, we are saving the data from the attributes of that object.
answers.comments_html: This one is a bit tricky! We are not able to save the object itself into our database; instead, we are saving the data from the attributes of that object.

answers.comments: Right! We are not able to save the object itself into our database; instead, we are saving the data from the attributes of that object.
answers.comments_html: Right! We are not able to save the object itself into our database; instead, we are saving the data from the attributes of that object.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are advantages of using an ORM? Select all that apply.

answers.text: It allows us to abstract common database tasks into methods.
answers.comments: Right! Abstraction is a very powerful tool that can make it much easier to grow our applications.
answers.comments_html:
Right! Abstraction is a very powerful tool that can make it much easier to
grow our applications.

answers.text: It cuts down on repetitive code.
answers.comments: Right! It's quite convenient to have a Python class that knows how to insert records into SQL rather than having to write that code out by hand.

answers.text: It sets up a consistent, logical relationship between object-oriented code and database tables.
answers.html:
It sets up a consistent, logical relationship between object-oriented code and
database tables.
answers.comments: Bingo! This pattern is a very common way to communicate with databases, and following these conventions makes it easier to add more features as our applications grow by giving us a clear design to follow.
answers.comments_html:
Bingo! This pattern is a very common way to communicate with databases, and
following these conventions makes it easier to add more features as our
applications grow by giving us a clear design to follow.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.
